time_trend_data.indicator_description: In New York City, the most common cause of lead poisoning in non-pregnant adults is from occupational exposure in the construction industry. Workers are exposed by breathing in or ingesting lead dust or fumes during renovations, repairs and demolitions that disturb old, lead based paint. Workers in other industries, as well as hobbyists, may be at risk if they work with lead-containing metal, paint, pigments, ceramic glazes or bullets. Adults can also be exposed to lead through the use of lead-contaminated products, such as certain imported health remedies or medicines, spices, foods, pottery and cosmetics.
time_trend_data.indicator_name: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among Persons Aged 16 or Older

Compare.graph_title: Trends in  Elevated Blood Lead Levels among  Persons Aged 16 or Older - 3-Year Average Annual Rate BLL >= 10 µg/dL 2001-2003 to 2012-2014
Compare.y_axis_title: 3-Year Average Annual Rate BLL >= 10 µg/dL (per 100,000 employed)

info.info_name: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among Persons Aged 16 or Older
info.info_how_calculated: Number of NYC residents aged 16 years and older with blood lead levels greater than or equal to 10 micrograms per deciliter over the 3-year period, divided by the employed NYC population aged 16 years or older in each of the 3 years, expressed as 3-year average annual rate per 100,000 employed persons.
info.info_source: New York State Heavy Metal Registry, U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Current Population Survey
